desc: This audio file describes the traditions and significance of Diwali, a major Hindu festival celebrated in India and Nepal.

sttData.content: Diwali, also referred to as the festival of lights, is a significant religious and cultural event celebrated by millions of Hindus, Jains, and Sikhs across the world.
The festival is celebrated every year in autumn, usually falling between October and November in the Gregorian calendar.

The origins of Diwali are deeply rooted in various mythological stories. According to the Hindu mythology, Diwali marks the return of Lord Rama from a 14-year exile and his victory over the demon king Ravana.
The festival is celebrated by decorating houses, lighting diyas (oil lamps) and candles, bursting firecrackers, and preparing special delicacies like puran poli and chakli.
Diwali also symbolizes the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance. It is a time for renewal, forgiveness, and unity among family and friends.

stt.sttSummary: Diwali, a major Hindu festival, celebrates the return of Lord Rama from exile and marks the victory of light over darkness.
